keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing guns, raising constitutional questions about the Second Amendment.
The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistani citizen, who was prosecuted for possessing a firearm and marijuana and cocaine at his home, with the government citing habitual drug use.
A federal district court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court precedent that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots and be analogous to past laws.
The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the precedent, ruling that prohibitions against habitual drug users are not historically supported.
The Trump administration appealed that decision, arguing that habitual drug users pose a danger to public safety, especially during impaired encounters with police.
The administration cited evidence from a 2019 border search and claims of Hemani's travel to Iran to celebrate Qasem Soleimani's death, which may be used to justify the prosecution.
Hemani's legal team countered that the historical basis for the law is weak and pointed to the fact that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana.
President Joe Biden's son, Hunter Biden, was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned, adding political sensitivity to the case.
The case is part of a broader trend of Supreme Court scrutiny of gun laws, including a separate case about whether states can restrict gun carrying on private property without owner consent.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that prohibits certain drug users from possessing firearms, focusing on whether such a ban violates the Second Amendment. The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistani citizen convicted in 2023 for possessing a firearm and drugs, with prosecutors arguing that habitual drug use poses a public safety risk. A lower court dismissed the charge, citing a 2022 Supreme Court precedent that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots. The 5th Circuit upheld that precedent, ruling that prohibitions against habitual users lack historical support. The Trump administration appealed, claiming that such users present dangerous risks, especially when impaired and interacting with law enforcement. The case is complicated by political dimensions, including the prior conviction of President Joe Biden’s son, Hunter Biden, under the same law, and the assertion that Hemani traveled to Iran to celebrate the killing of Qasem Soleimani. Legal arguments center on whether the law’s historical foundation is sound, especially in light of the growing legalization of marijuana in nearly half of U.S. states. The Supreme Court is expected to hear arguments next year and issue a decision by the end of June 2026.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
